a thin membrane  - The central crura meet and form a cross 
under the centre of the disc - The lateral crura are continuous 
with the substance of the disc above and each meets with 
its fellow external to the centre of the disc (Fig. 26) The central 
crura are united with these and thence with the disc by 
the thin membrane only. It thence follows that there 
exists above the central crura and the connecting membrane 
a wide crucial cavity - into this the canals of the suspending 
pillars open and from it radiate the canals which are given 
off to the circumference of the disc - The crucial cavity there 
is only a portion of the great system of canals 
[paragraph].47. The external surface of the outer half of the thin uniting 
membrane (which is composed solely of the two "foundation 
membranes" is produced into a vast number of transverse folds 
of a greyish green colour in the male but of a deep orange 
red in the female (fig.26) These give rise to the appearance of a 
coloured cross shining through when the  disc is viewed 
from above - The inner <s>a<\s> side of  the folds is beset 
with a series of tentacles, the generative tentacles, described 
above ([paragraph] 31.)(fig. 30) In young specimens not more than 
three inches in diameter the generative organs were 
underdeveloped. The outer portions of the thin membrane 
being as smooth as the inner but the series of tentacles 
already existed* 
In adults the margins of the folds contain the spermatozoa 
in the male the ova in the female 

*Note. It appears to me that M. Milne Edwards must have had a 
young individual of <u>Rhizostoma<u> before him when
